questions.question: A $10 \text{ kg}$ sled travels down a $20 \text{ m}$ snowy slope at an angle of $20^\circ$. The coefficient of kinetic friction is $0.10$. Calculate the initial potential energy. (Use $g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)

A $10 \text{ kg}$ sled travels down a $20 \text{ m}$ snowy slope at an angle of $20^\circ$. The coefficient of kinetic friction is $0.10$. Calculate the energy lost to heat. (Use $g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)

A $3 \text{ kg}$ package slides down a $6 \text{ m}$ chute inclined at $37^\circ$. The friction force is a constant $5 \text{ N}$. What is the mechanical energy of the package at the bottom of the chute if it started from rest? (Use $g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)
Which statement best describes the Law of Conservation of Energy in a system with friction?
options: Energy is not conserved because friction 'uses it up.'
Total energy (including heat) is conserved, but mechanical energy is not.
Mechanical energy is conserved regardless of friction.
Friction creates new energy to replace the lost kinetic energy.
questions.explanation: Total energy is always conserved. Friction converts mechanical energy to heat.

questions.question: To prepare for a winter sprint, a $520$ g chipmunk performs $40$ rapid pushups in $60$ seconds. During each upward movement, the chipmunk lifts its center of mass by $10.0$ cm. Calculate the total work performed by the chipmunk during the upward phase of all $40$ pushups. (Use $g = 9.8 \text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Mass = 0.52 kg, $W_{per pushup} = 0.52 \times 9.8 \times 0.10 = 0.5096$ J. Total = $40 \times 0.5096 = 20.384 \approx 20.4$ J.

questions.question: An $80 \text{ kg}$ cliff diver jumps from a $30 \text{ m}$ platform. What is the diver's kinetic energy when they are exactly $15 \text{ m}$ above the water? (Use $g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)

A $75 \text{ kg}$ skydiver falls from a plane at $3000 \text{ m}$. If we ignore air resistance for the first part of the fall, what is their velocity after they have descended to an altitude of $2500 \text{ m}$? (Use $g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2$)
A $2.0\text{ kg}$ object is moving with an initial velocity of $2.0\text{ m/s}$. If a net work of $100\text{ J}$ is performed on the object in the direction of its motion, calculate its final speed.

A $2500\text{ kg}$ truck traveling at $15\text{ m/s}$ comes to a sudden stop, transferring its total kinetic energy into a $5\text{ kg}$ projectile. Calculate the launch velocity of the projectile, assuming no energy is lost to heat or sound.

A $15\text{ kg}$ object is moving at a constant velocity of $80\text{ m/s}$. If this object strikes a stationary $25\text{ kg}$ mass and transfers $100\%$ of its kinetic energy to it, what will be the resulting velocity of the $25\text{ kg}$ mass?

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered energy conservation problems.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! Review how to account for energy losses due to friction.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on $PE_i = KE_f + E_{lost}$ type problems.
scoreMessages.0: Let's review. Study how mechanical energy transforms and how friction dissipates energy.
